content.headline: Global Breastfeeding Guidelines for Optimal Child Health
content.intro: Breastmilk is the ideal food for infants - safe, clean and containing antibodies that protect against common childhood illnesses. However, fewer than half of infants under 6 months old are exclusively breastfed worldwide.

sections.title: WHO and UNICEF Recommendations
sections.content: Follow these evidence-based guidelines for optimal breastfeeding:
points: Initiate breastfeeding within the first hour of birth
Exclusive breastfeeding for the first 6 months of life
Continue breastfeeding for up to two years or beyond
Breastfeed on demand - as often as the child wants
No bottles, teats or pacifiers should be used initially

sections.title: Benefits of Breastfeeding
sections.content: Breastfeeding provides lifelong advantages for both mother and child:
points: Breastfed children perform better on intelligence tests
Reduced risk of overweight, obesity and diabetes later in life
Lower risk of breast and ovarian cancers for mothers
Provides all energy and nutrients for first months of life
Continues to provide significant nutrition through second year

sections.title: Global Breastfeeding Initiatives
sections.content: WHO is working to improve breastfeeding rates worldwide:
points: Aiming for 50% exclusive breastfeeding rate by 2025
Global Breastfeeding Collective rallies political support
NetCode prevents inappropriate marketing of breast-milk substitutes
Training courses for health workers to support mothers
Monitoring growth and development of breastfed children

sections.title: Complementary Feeding
sections.content: When and how to introduce solid foods:
points: Begin safe complementary foods from age 6 months
Continue breastfeeding while introducing solids
Ensure complementary foods are nutritionally adequate
Maintain breastfeeding during illness episodes
Gradually increase food variety and texture
